You are referring to the book "A People's History of the United States" by Howard Zinn. This influential work was first published in 1980 and has since become a classic in the field of American history.

The book offers a different perspective on American history, focusing on the experiences of marginalized groups such as indigenous peoples, women, people of color, and the working class. Zinn argues that traditional histories of the United States have been told from the perspective of the wealthy and powerful, and that by focusing on these perspectives, the experiences and struggles of ordinary people have been ignored.

"A People's History of the United States" covers American history from Columbus's arrival in the Americas to the late 20th century, and it challenges the notion of American exceptionalism and the idea that the country has always been a beacon of freedom and democracy. Instead, Zinn argues that the US has been marked by a history of exploitation, oppression, and the pursuit of wealth and power.

The book has been widely read and has been both celebrated and criticized for its perspective on American history. It has been used in classrooms across the country and has influenced a generation of scholars and activists.
